Game-Jam Entry : Soko-GardenMake your flowers grow and create a beautiful garden in this Sokoban-inspired game made for Wild Jam #85 (theme: Expansion).‚Üí Try it on itch.io :) Context #For Wild Jam #85, we challenged ourselves to learn game development with Godot 4.5. We only had about three days to work on the project and used a free asset pack for the game‚Äôs visuals.
The theme of the jam was ‚ÄúExpansion.‚Äù
At first, we weren‚Äôt very inspired, but then the idea came: make flowers grow. With the limited time and the challenge of learning a new engine (being more familiar with Unity and Unreal), we focused on keeping the concept achievable.
Both of us worked on the game design and programming.
Game Design #Since this was a game jam, the design process was intentionally light. We brainstormed the concept together and iterated on the mechanics while implementing them.
One of our main discussions was whether to use a grid-based movement system. The goal was not to create a challenging Sokoban-like game, so the character‚Äôs movement was designed to be free. However, for the pushed objects, we restricted them to a grid to ensure the puzzles worked as intended.
I also designed and implemented the levels.
Programming #As this was my first experience with programming, I couldn‚Äôt contribute to the more complex systems, but I still helped with:
Integrating the character animations (from the asset pack)
Implementing character movement
Beginning the integration of sound design

My Master‚Äôs Thesis [French]La "cam√©ra" vid√©oludique et son importance dans les attitudes interactionnelles chez le joueur.‚Üí Read it on Academia.eduAbstract #Ce m√©moire √©tudie l‚Äôimpact de la cam√©ra vid√©oludique sur les attitudes interactionnelles du joueur gr√¢ce aux notions telles que l‚Äôocularisation, la focalis‚Äôaction, les modes de visualisation et les modalit√©s du faire. En croisant toutes ces notions dans l‚Äôanalyses de cinq jeux (Prey, Control, Children of the Sun, Crow Country et Heartworm), on remarque que les cam√©ras plus permissives augmentent les pouvoir-faire du joueur, mais √©galement les savoir-faire demand√©s. Lier ces crit√®res d‚Äôanalyses de l‚Äôimage a aussi permis de voir l‚Äôocularisation vid√©oludique sous le prisme des attitudes interactionnelles. On peut noter aussi que les diff√©rents crit√®res du point de vue au jeu vid√©o participent √† l‚Äôaction de jouer et d√©finissent une vraie identit√© ludique propre √† chaque titre. L‚Äô√©tude pr√©sent√©e dans ce m√©moire reste tout de m√™me marqu√©e par la subjectivit√© de cette approche.
Introduction #La notion de point de vue est l‚Äôune des notions les plus fondamentales du jeu vid√©o : il d√©finit l‚Äôidentit√© visuelle d‚Äôun jeu, mais est aussi et surtout un outil fonctionnel qui conditionne la mani√®re dont le joueur per√ßoit et d√©veloppe des attitudes ludiques. Le point de vue devient alors une m√©canique de jeu √† part enti√®re o√π le joueur est invit√© √† ‚Äújouer √† voir‚Äù en contr√¥lant son point de vue pour progresser, c‚Äôest la ‚Äúvision act√©e‚Äù.
En effet, bien qu‚Äôappel√©e ‚Äúcam√©ra‚Äù depuis quelques ann√©es en raison des rapprochements entre le jeu vid√©o et le cin√©ma, le point de vue vid√©oludique a su s‚Äôaffranchir de la cam√©ra cin√©matographique par un ensemble de caract√©ristiques qui lui sont propres.
L√† o√π la cam√©ra physique au cin√©ma fonctionne par captation de lumi√®re, la cam√©ra ‚Äúvid√©oludique‚Äù est un ensemble de lignes de code qui calcule en temps r√©el un rendu et qui le projette √† l‚Äô√©cran, c‚Äôest une cam√©ra simul√©e.
Ce terme de ‚Äúcam√©ra‚Äù emprunt√© au cin√©ma, Selim Krichane, docteur en cin√©ma et game studies, l‚Äôexplique dans certains de ses ouvrages ou articles comme ‚ÄúLa cam√©ra imaginaire‚Äù (2018) ou ‚ÄúJeu vid√©o et cin√©ma‚Äù (2023) par les interm√©dialit√©s croissantes entre le jeu vid√©o et le cin√©ma dans les ann√©es 90 √† l‚Äôav√®nement des jeux en 3-dimension. Pour analyser pertinemment cette ‚Äúcam√©ra‚Äù, il met en avant des crit√®res qui seront d√©finis et utilis√©s dans ce travail et qui permettent de d√©finir des points cl√©s de l‚Äôimage vid√©oludique : la projection, la translation, l‚Äôactivation et le degr√© d‚Äôiconicit√©.
La cam√©ra vid√©oludique est essentielle dans l‚Äôexercice ludique du joueur, car c‚Äôest lui qui va faire avancer le jeu. La vision act√©e devient alors une m√©canique qui permet de r√©guler la compr√©hension du joueur et le faire agir sur le jeu : ce sont ses attitudes interactionnelles. On peut illustrer ce principe avec des jeux comme Hellblade : Senua‚Äôs Sacrifice (Ninja Theory, 2017) ou The Witness (Thekla Inc., 2016) qui demandent au joueur d‚Äôaligner leur point de vue √† des √©l√©ments du jeu pour r√©soudre des √©nigmes. Ce principe, qui d√©crit la fa√ßon dont le jeu communique ses informations pour que le joueur r√©gule ses actions, est √©tudi√© dans le document ‚ÄúLa Focalis-action : Des savoirs narratifs aux faires vid√©oludiques‚Äù (2018) de Hugo Montembeault et Bernard Perron.
Cette notion de focalis‚Äôaction est un prolongement des concepts de focalisation (ce que l‚Äôon sait) et d‚Äôocularisation (ce que l‚Äôon voit) qui r√©gulent les informations narratives et visuelles en y ajoutant l‚Äôinteractivit√© du jeu.
La ‚Äúcam√©ra‚Äù vid√©oludique devient alors le point central reliant les propositions interactionnelles du jeu avec les actions ludiques du joueur. Probl√©matique L‚Äôint√©r√™t de l‚Äô√©tude de ce sujet vient alors dans l‚Äôimportance que le point de vue a sur l‚Äôexp√©rience ludique. Et on peut alors supposer que des diff√©rences sont notables entre les modes de visualisation ou de restriction de l‚Äôinformation, surtout quand c‚Äôest au joueur de contr√¥ler son point de vue. D√®s lors, la question que l‚Äôon se posera tout au long de cette r√©flexion est la suivante :
‚ÄúComment le contr√¥le de la cam√©ra vid√©oludique actualise les principes d‚Äôocularisation et influence les attitudes interactionnelles du joueur?‚Äù

Context #This game was created during our two-year Master‚Äôs program by a team of ten, each contributing to every aspect of the project.
The playable version features about 45 minutes of gameplay and serves as the first level of our broader game concept. While time limitations and other challenges prevented us from completing the full game, this prototype demonstrates our some of our vision and ambition on a limited scale.
PreviousNextGame Design #Rigging & Skinning #PreviousNextAll rigs in the project were created in Maya using the Advanced Skeleton plugin, which offers a free version for non-commercial projects.
The rig went through several versions throughout the project, as I applied improvements and fixes over time, even though most of the core work was done in the first version.
3D Animation & Tech Anim #I worked on almost all the animations for the main character. We had another Game Animator in the team who worked on NPCs.
The animations were made with Autodesk Maya 2024 and integrated into Unreal Engine 5.
Sound Design #Footsteps integration #For the integration, the sounds were linked to animations. It was therefore necessary to create events at the right moments within the animation in Unreal.
More complex were the footsteps and clothing sounds, which were all grouped into a single audio cue containing footsteps on different surfaces: dirt, stone, grass, and wood.
Before sending them to the output, a switch had to be added between different numeric values tied to a variable we called Surface.
These numbers corresponded to Unreal‚Äôs surface types. After creating the appropriate Physics Materials for each sound and applying them in the Unreal settings, the footsteps could react depending on the surface the character was walking on.
This Switch/Surface method is highly modular, as it allows you to progressively add new sounds for new terrains, which we did over the course of the project.
Physics settingsAmbiences #For the ambiences, the goal was to have a natural and relaxing atmosphere outdoors, contrasted with a heavier atmosphere in the depths. They were created in Reaper, our DAW of choice for this thesis project, while the interiors were mostly refined during integration using effects like reverb (see the integration section).
For the caves, I wanted to create a sense of discomfort, since our concept was to play on the dissonance of a disturbing cozy game.
To highlight this dissonance, the outdoors needed to feel warm and comforting, while the indoors had to be more unsettling. That required different ambiences and additional sounds, with a clear distinction between the two.
To make the caves feel more threatening and isolated, I deliberately avoided adding any creature sounds. I also used an Audio Volume with reverb, applied selectively thanks to sound class sorting (obviously I didn‚Äôt want reverb on music or UI sounds).
Meanwhile, outdoors, I wanted bird sound effects all around the player to create a sense of being surrounded by life.
Music Integration #The game features three music tracks: one for the main menu, one for outdoor areas, and one for indoor areas.
Together with the composer, we were inspired by the approach used in Minecraft: the music often gives way to ambient sound and restarts randomly, making it less repetitive and more surprising.
The system is extremely simple. It selects a random delay between two values, plays the music, and once finished, relaunches it after another delay.
I also used the Audio Volumes already set up for ambiences so that outdoor music only plays outside, and indoor music only inside.
SFX #Random Sound Zone #One effect I wanted to add in the caves to reinforce the unsettling atmosphere was a system that plays sounds randomly in 3D space around the player.
This system was implemented with the help of our programmer.
It works by triggering an event with a random delay between two min/max values defined in the editor.
Once triggered, it picks a random point within a predefined zone, also set up in the editor, where we can define the radius.
End Cutscene & Trailer #Cutscene #The ending cutscene was created entirely in Unreal Engine using the Video Sequencer, while the sound design was completed in Premiere Pro.
Trailer #The trailer was also made using Unreal‚Äôs Video Sequencer and Premiere Pro. It combines staged shots with gameplay footage captured with OBS.
Team Members #
